featuresPageHeroBannerSubtitle: First USD-pegged stablecoin underpinned by a decentralized scalable Bitcoin-backed asset.
featuresPageFirstFeatureDescription: Threshold USD is a decentralized borrowing protocol that allows you to draw loans using tBTC or ETH as collateral. Loans are issued in thUSD (a USD pegged stablecoin) and must maintain a minimum collateral ratio of 110% to avoid liquidation.
featuresPageSecondFeatureDescription: As a non-custodial system, all the tokens sent to the protocol will be held and managed algorithmically without the interference of any person or legal entity. That means your funds will only be subject to the rules set forth in the smart contract code.
featuresPageThirdFeatureDescription: With a low 0.9% interest rate for tBTC and ETH, and an optimal 110% minimum collateral ratio for enhanced efficiency. Relying on a minimal governance, most of the protocol operations are algorithmic and fully automated, and thUSD can be directly redeemed for the underlying collateral at any time.

featuresPageFourthQuestion: Can Threshold USD be upgraded or changed?
featuresPageFourthAnswer: Yes. The Threshold USD token contracts mint function will be able to add additional contracts; this is how we keep the option to upgrade while leaving the thUSD contract immutable.
featuresPageFifthQuestion: Why would I use Threshold USD for borrowing?
featuresPageFifthAnswerFirstParagraph: Threshold USD protocol offers low interest loans and is more capital efficient than other borrowing systems (i.e. less collateral is needed for the same loan). Instead of selling tBTC to have liquid funds, you can use the protocol to lock up your tBTC, borrow against the collateral to withdraw thUSD, and then repay your loan at a future date.
featuresPageFifthAnswerSecondParagraph: For example: Borrowers speculating on future tBTC price increases can use the protocol to leverage their tBTC positions up to 11 times, increasing their exposure to price changes. This is possible because thUSD can be borrowed against tBTC, sold on the open market to purchase more tBTC — rinse and repeat.*
featuresPageFifthAnswerThirdParagraph: *Note: This is NOT a recommendation for how to use Threshold USD. Leverage can be very risky as you can lose all your funds and should be used only by those with experience and for speculative amounts.
featuresPageSixthQuestion: What do I need in order to use Threshold USD?
featuresPageSixthAnswerFirstParagraphFir: To borrow thUSD, all you need is a wallet (e.g. MetaMask or
featuresPageSixthAnswerFirstParagraphSec: ) and sufficient tBTC or ETH to open a Vault and pay the gas fees.
featuresPageSixthAnswerSecondParagraph: To become a Stability Pool depositor you need to have thUSD, which can be borrowed by opening a Vault. You can also use Curve or another (decentralized) exchange to buy the tokens on the open market.
featuresPageSeventhQuestion: How can I borrow with Threshold USD?
featuresPageSeventhAnswer: To borrow you must open a Vault and deposit a certain amount of collateral (tBTC) to it. Then you can draw thUSD up to a collateral ratio of 110%. A minimum debt of 2,000 thUSD is required. This minimum debt threshold prevents an attacker from creating a large number of Vaults that are then unprofitable to liquidate.
featuresPageEighthQuestion: How does thUSD closely follow the price of USD?
featuresPageEighthAnswerFirstParagraph: The ability to redeem thUSD for tBTC at face value (i.e. 1 thUSD for $1 of tBTC) and the minimum collateral ratio of 110% create a price floor and price ceiling (respectively) through arbitrage opportunities. We call these hard peg mechanisms, since they are based on direct processes.
featuresPageEighthAnswerSecondParagraph: thUSD also benefits from less direct mechanisms for USD parity — called soft peg mechanisms. One of these mechanisms is parity as a Schelling point. Since Threshold USD treats thUSD as being equal to USD, parity between the two is an implied equilibrium state of the protocol. Another of these mechanisms is the borrowing fee on new debts. As redemptions increase (implying thUSD is below $1), so too does the baseRate — making borrowing less attractive which keeps new thUSD from hitting the market and driving the price below $1.
featuresPageEighthAnswerThirdParagraphFi: Liquity (on which thUSD Protocol is based on) did a thorough analysis on the price stability of LUSD
featuresPageEighthAnswerThirdParagraphTh: This analysis is equally relevant for thUSD.
featuresPageNinthAnswerFirstParagraph: A redemption is the process of exchanging thUSD for tBTC at face value, as if 1 thUSD is exactly worth $1. That is, for x thUSD you get x Dollars worth of tBTC in return.
featuresPageNinthAnswerSecondParagraph: Users can redeem their thUSD for tBTC at any time without limitations. However, a redemption fee might be charged on the redeemed amount.
featuresPageNinthAnswerThirdParagraph: For example, if the current redemption fee is 1%, the price of tBTC is $50,000 and you redeem 10,000 thUSD, you would get 0.198 tBTC (0.2 tBTC minus a redemption fee of 0.002 tBTC).
featuresPageNinthAnswerFourthParagraph: Note that the redeemed amount is taken into account for calculating the base rate and might have an impact on the redemption fee, especially if the amount is large.
featuresPageTenthQuestion: Is redemption the same as paying back my debt?
featuresPageTenthAnswer: No, redemptions are a completely separate mechanism. All one has to do to pay back their debt is adjust their Vault's debt and collateral.
featuresPageEleventhQuestion: How is the redemption fee calculated?
featuresPageEleventhAnswer: Under normal operation, the redemption fee is given by the formula (baseRate + 0.5%) * tBTCdrawn
featuresPageTwelfthAnswerFirstParagraph: Recovery Mode kicks in when the Total Collateral Ratio (TCR) of the system falls below 150%.
featuresPageTwelfthAnswerSecondParagraph: During Recovery Mode, Vaults with a collateral ratio below 150% can be liquidated.
featuresPageTwelfthAnswerThirdParagraph: Moreover, the system blocks borrower transactions that would further decrease the TCR. New LUSD may only be issued by adjusting existing Vaults in a way that improves their collateral ratio, or by opening a new Vault with a collateral ratio greater than 150%. In general, if an existing Vault's adjustment reduces its collateral ratio, the transaction is only executed if the resulting TCR is above 150%.
featuresPageThirteenthQuestion: What is the Total Collateral Ratio?
featuresPageThirteenthAnswer: The Total Collateral Ratio or TCR is the ratio of the Dollar value of the entire system collateral at the current ETH:USD price, to the entire system debt. In other words, it's the sum of the collateral of all Vaults expressed in USD, divided by the debt of all Vaults expressed in LUSD.
